page.title: 11THE RIVER RIB VALLEY.
page.content: The River Rib,a tributary of the River Lee,flows through a wide and gently sloping valley. The river is usually unpolluted and the water clear. There are many fish,but trout,pike,dace and chow were introduced recently,as there were not enough to allow good fishing. Six people put in 300 brown and rainbow trout in April and July,to keep the stocks up. The Thames Water Authority electrocutes the coarse fish each year,as they eat the others. There are many fords across the river. The largest is at Barwick,which is a popular "beauty-spot". The river banks are very unspoilt and the wildlife is abundant. Commonly found are,herons, kingfishers,yellow-hammers,pheasants, mallards,tits,dab-chicks,rabbits,swans and swallows. The Lee Valley Water Company,take water from the river at the Cold Christmas pumping station.
